Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story: I stood in the hospital corridor, my phone pressed tightly to my ear. My stepbrother’s voice trembled as he told me about the news—our dad’s cancer had returned. He was breaking down, and I could hear the pain in every word. I wanted nothing more than to be there for him, to listen, to reassure him that we’d get through this together. But just as I tried to comfort him, I heard a sob from the room behind me. Mrs. Carter, my patient, had just learned her cancer was terminal. She was alone, her hands shaking, tears streaming down her face. As a nursing assistant, I was expected to be her anchor, to sit with her, hold her hand, and help her through the shock. My heart pulled in two directions—my stepbrother needed me, but so did Mrs. Carter. I felt the weight of both their pain pressing on my chest, and I stood frozen, torn between the two people who needed me most.
